reviewText:
Imagine a gorgeous, detailed graphical story. A story of goblins, dragons, wonderful lands and gorgeous colour. Imagine a story made of heroes undertaking an epic quest to protect the kingdom from a terrible menace and journeying far and wide. Now imagine that story being brought to life, animated, and you being in control of the heroes. That's Trine 2.

The artwork is jaw dropping, not because of technical wizardry or the number of polygons it pushes on screen, this isn't a game that will murder your graphics card, but instead the artistry comes from attention to detail. The watercolour feel of the skies, the glorious use of colours and sweeping vistas to sell the graphical novel element, and the heroes and villains, brought to being in near hand drawn detail. Behind this rests a solid, if somewhat generic feeling soundtrack, but a narrator who really sells the atmosphere, combined with solid voice acting for each of the protagonists (and indeed, the antagonists), it helps immerse you in the game and the story as a whole.

The mechanics of the game are a refinement and improvement over the original Trine, with you switching between heroes on the fly and using their respective strengths to fight and puzzle your way through various environments, however this time it feels much slicker, and much more confident in what it does, there's many points where you'll be scratching your head, only to have the light flick on with a genuine AH HA!" moment. It's never punishingly difficult

reviewText:
TRINE 2: COMPLETE STORY
A majestic platform puzzle game with a dash of action.

Rating 6/10

It’s similar in many ways to the classic Shadow of the Beast series and The Lost Vikings. You take control of one of three heroes, a wizard, thief and knight, whilst being able to character swap at any time even mid jump.  It's this fluid change from styles in the middle of battle or solving a puzzle that adds another dimension to what could turn into fairly simplistic gameplay. There are times when it doesn't work such as having your thief or knight die and only being left with a wizard who is rather useless in a fight. However there are enough character reviving checkpoints that it doesn't become too much of an annoying handicap.

Despite being a fairly traditional side scrolling platform game it's a truly beautifully made game, in artistic terms it's near perfect. It's this beauty coupled with the fun physics puzzles and quick action that keeps you playing as the plot is non-existent and the voice acting is weak.

The DLC adds a few new environments such as dusty desert and the inside of a giant worm and whilst every bit as stunning as the main game by this stage Trine 2 has overstayed it's welcome and it's a fairly boring slog through the last seven extra levels. The DLC doesn't add any real new mechanics or gameplay, it’s just more of the same.

So whilst trine 2 doesn't offer much in the way of innovative gameplay or a great story it's beauty has to be seen.

reviewText:
Trine 2 is a wonderful physics-based platformer. The levels are all well-designed and afford just the right amount of leeway to let the player figure out creative solutions to obstacles. All three heroes that the player (or players - the game has online co-op that works great) controls have unique abilities that can be combined in clever ways to traverse the environments. Sometimes it feels like you can abuse the physics engine to bypass things, but I'm pretty sure most of it is intentional, as the inverse that is often present in physics-based platformers just isn't there: you'll never feel like you came up with a solution that should have worked but got cheated because the physics went wonky. It's just the right blend of physics sandbox and puzzle game.

The only real issue is the combat. It's super simple, and so long as your warrior is alive, absolutely trivial. It's perhaps best to treat enemies as just another physics toy. Fighting them hand-to-hand quickly becomes dull, but you can pick up enemies as the wizard and see how they're affected by the environment. Thankfully, it's a small enough part of the game that I don't think anyone should be dissuaded by my complaints, especially since respawning at a checkpoint doesn't reset enemies, so you never ever have to go through a fight again.

On the presentation side, Trine 2 is absolutely flawless. The supersaturated graphics are utterly gorgeous. Every single frame of this game would make an excellent wallpaper. It simply is that beautiful. The audio is perfect, with great music and excellent voice work. And the story is simple but very well written and charming. Everything comes together to look, feel, and sound like a fairy tale.

reviewText:
Platformers come in many shapes.
Twitch-platformers and reflex-platfomers, which I can't stand, and puzzle, action, and physics platformers, which I enjoy.

Trine 2 is an action-puzzle platformer, maintaining a good, steady progression flow [versus getting stuck trying to hit the same platform jump for 10 minutes, like some platformers], offering a good variety of physics, combat, and puzzle challenges.

Few of these challenges will be overly demanding on you- combat especially isn't meant to hinder your progres as much as offer palate cleansing or distractions to puzzles,

But there's a lot of creativity and style in the game, and it ends up being enjoyable in the same way all the best classic [eg, nothing like Meat Boy] platformers are.



PROS

*Fun single-player with plenty of unlocks and secrets, that manages to keep you steadily 'just challenged enough' to make for a relaxing-yet-stimulating engagement.

*Astoundingly good co-op. You thought single player was fun? Imagine being able to leverage your partner for crazy combos, reinterpret all the puzzles in new and delightfully clever ways, and, best of all?
'Accidentally' drop your partner into lava, drop a box on their head, or smash the platform they're floating on.
Hey, it's what friends are for.

*Co-op is easy to set up, has a decent selection of hosting options, and plays very smoothly.

*Good variety of stages
Stages range from small dungeon corridors, to open city or dungeon expanses, to vertical shafts, to underwater caverns, to skyscapes and more. I never found myself dissatisfied with stage progression.

*Good variety of puzzles

*Good variety of unlocks

*Good, consistant blend of action, combat, puzzling, platforming.

*Very stable (very few bugs and no major bugs)


NEUTRAL

*Each stage tends to emphasize the same enemies. Would have been nice if there was more variety and sub-bosses.

*The expansion abilities offer tons of fun new dynamics- but can significantly reduce game difficulty.

*While the stages and enemies have flair and creativity, there's no story whatsoever to speak of. Generally not something that platformer players really worry about but since this is also RPG, I'm going to make a note that's a tag based only in being able to find items to gear your characters up with, and being able to unlock/upgrade abilities.

*Workshop support, but last time I checked, no legitimately decent offerings. The few that look good, tend to have a lot of bugs, like falling into or through terrain.

*The characters are a bit dim. The humor here is definitely subjective, though thankfully, never offensive or intrusive [think mild 'you're so fat' and fart referencing humor].


CONS

*The expansion content feels like a clumsy afterthought. If you already own Trine 2, you really don't need to buy Complete Story unless you really want to play the main game again, and try the new expansion abilities in it.

---

This game is one of my absolute favorite co-op games, and if you're at all into co-op gaming, I can't recommend it enough.
The most 'nasty' things are spike pits, carnivorous plants, skeletons, and goblins, so it should be playable with relatively young children, as the game doesn't include gore, frights, or offensive humor.

4.5/5


Bonus:
If you like Trine 2, you may also want to give Ibb & Obb a look- it's a pure puzzle-physics platformer, so a different vibe, but it has good puzzling co-op (and is far more of a challenge for the brain than Trine 2). Do however note that there's a bug that, if not yet fixed, makes the last level unable to be completed for a small number of players.

Trine 2 is easily one of the most beautiful games today. It is a really addictive game, with an innovative approach to the platformer genre.

The main point that makes Trine 2 so enjoyable is that it requires thought to play: you have to solve puzzle after puzzle in each screen, and eventually fight some enemies and bosses. There are plenty of bosses.

Another nice thing (for me, at least) about Trine 2 is that the difficult increases gradually, but the curve is not too steep: you get a chance to learn how things work in Trine 2's world, and how your powers work.

Trine 2's characters are very well designed, and they complement each other nicely, leaving nothing to be desired.

All in all, Trine 2 deserves one of those Oscars for games, if there were one.

The only downside I see in Trine 2 is that some of the Steam Achievements are nearly impossible to get, but that doesn't get in the way of the game at all.

I highly recommend Trine 2.

Fun characters, divine graphics- the starting point for an impressive gameplay. Still, I never would have thought that a sequel was going to animate my screen and I couldn’t have been more wrong about it.  Trine 2 is here, I’ve played it and, since I’m a hard-working guy, here’s a very meticulous review.

Same as the first game, the three heroes, The Wiseman, The Knight and The Thief…pardon me, I meant The “Inventive woman” are united by a magical artifact called The Trine, whose goal is to protect the land from a new threat. Therefore, the inevitable goblin infestation. So, the three characters are up for a new adventure which, unlike the first game, takes a little longer time to play.

In a very bizarre way, Trine 2 makes me think of Terry Pratcher’s novels, maybe because of its strange atmosphere that I picked up by reading this author’s books. The Universe presented in this title is so subtle that you can only be overwhelmed with its complexity. Even if it is an Indie game that we are talking about, the narrative value can not be ignored since this time, the characters are better shaped by their developers, humanized I might say, from the voiceover’s point of view as well as from the action’s point of view. I will even go further and say that Trine 2 offers a very pleasant story for all ages, even if it’s a 12+ game, precisely because the narration has something to offer to everyone. Nostalgic to say at least! Still, there are some missing bricks to this wall. The key of this story is nice indeed, but the main problem is the poor narrative construction. I think everybody would have been happier if someone would have added some solid touches to this aspect. The motivations are clear, meaning that the land is full of goblins, but the story as a whole concept could have been more complex. Who knows, maybe Trine 3 will surprise me when the time comes.

The three key-elements that a player must take into consideration when starting this game are : cooperation, cleverness and physics. These elements are as important as the three main characters. Even if, on a regular basis, Trine 2 is a platformer, these elements are very necessary while dealing with a certain level. At the beginning of the game, there is a tutorial to teach you what every character can do. The Wiseman, because he is your starting point, is not the every-day Gandalf that everyone got used to. He is more of a clumsy magician for he has no idea what a fire ball really is. Still, he has his own tips and tricks, he can make objects appear from nowhere, such as boxes, or even make them levitate to get to certain locations.

The Knight, on the other hand, is the muscled genius among the three characters. Even if he’s not very bright, he’s compensating by his strength, also being the best choice when it comes to a one on one fight with your enemies. Equipped with a shield, a hammer and a sword, he’s the defensive one of the trio. Last but not least, The Thief. And no, you’re not going to break chains or sneak behind your enemies, because her abilities are more rogue-like.
She has a hook to reach to certain points otherwise inaccessible and an elastic loop to fight at the distance. What’s truly interesting and new is the way you switch between these characters to complete a level. The puzzles are sometimes so twisted that they really work your cleverness off! But that doesn’t mean there’s only one way to deal with a puzzle. Frozenbyte finally made it with this platformer: the experience is multidimensional, despite of its puzzle-platformer prejudices. To solve a certain puzzle, the player has at least three ways, which is pretty unexpected among the game mechanics that other developers use.
The characters’ control is absolutely beautiful. After pressing a key or a button if you’re playing on a controller, the task is immediately registered by your game. This is one of the most satisfying platformers I’ve played since Sonic Generations. No platformer fanatic could ever find a misstep concerning this aspect. The game control is perfect, I would say.

Trine 2 is not only made of twisted puzzles, but also of battle sequences and a handful of bosses every now and then. These fights are meant to break the monotony of a certain level, full of enigmas. Still, the gameplay is so rewarding that the player can use his characters’ abilities to knock down the enemies. And because something had to be done when it came to options, each hero has a set of five abilities that can be improved using the experience points you get. What I find extremely stressful is that some of the abilities you get using this tree are only necessary for a specific level. The player has to reassign some of his points in order to finish a portion of the puzzle. I must say that this procedure is free, so you don’t have to repeat anything to get more experience afterwards.
One of the major gains of this game is the cooperative multi-player, online and local, a huge step from the previous game and probably one of the reasons for which we strongly recommend a bundle. Two more players can be added to one session, each one of them being able to control in an active way one of the three characters, which makes the puzzles a lot easier, as far as I’m concerned. That being said, I must admit that I found myself playing this game even for the third time, just because it’s fun to find new ways to complete a level: a very nice move coming from Frozenbyte, although Zon@ thinks they should have done this from the beginning.

We are finally getting to graphics. Did I mention this is an Indie game that comes from a small studio where are working about 20 people? Well, Trine 2 is a masterpiece of beauty. Want to hear something more spectacular that this? The game engine has been totally reconstructed. The game not only that looks divine, but its physics is very accurate. From the well animated background to the small details , nothing has been left out. And everything is the work of a very small, but talented, team. I know it sounds like I’m trying to get under their skin, but I’m telling the truth. The animations, the flow, the light and all the other elements gave me the impression that I was watching a moving painting. The colours also made a huge impression on me, one I will not easily forget.

The sound itself is quite an experience. Not only that the narrative part is well represented on script, but the voices and the entire performance of the characters are as authentic as they could be. It sounds just like a very posh movie. The soundtrack is exactly what the game needed to complete the atmosphere: the way it highlights the key points of the game makes your blood rush and your adrenaline keep pumping which turns the whole experience into a sound feast.

Is Trine 2 a good game? I’ve been praising it a lot so yes, it is! It’s one of those games you have to play in order to find out what a creative genius really means. If the first game managed to get my attention, Trine 2 has upgraded to a very high standard among platformers.

reviewText:
AT A GLANCE(Full review follows below)

Game Name: Trine 2: Complete Story
Original Release: 2013
Genre Tags: Platformer; Adventure; Puzzle; Coop; Beautiful Artwork
My Overall Grade: A
Estimated Playtime (Campaign): 10-25 hours
Multiplayer Aspect: Optional
Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; Those intrigued by the genre; Aesthetes; Game atmosphere connoisseurs; Casual gamers; Multiplayer gamers
REVIEWTrine 2 is the sequel to the instant classic that was the first.  And it successfully takes a big step forward from the first game in all the positive aspects.  However, not too much was changed, ensuring that the charm achieved in the first game is still prevalent. Like its forefather, Trine 2 is a light game that is easy to digest but offers gripping visuals, a mystical atmosphere, and enticing gameplay.  All of the features of the game are simple in design but intricate in execution.  The gameplay, aesthetics, and narrative all come together to create a whimsical and charming adventure.  I highly recommend this for all gamers to consider; and for fans of the genre it is a sure bet.

Keeping in the tradition of the first game, the best aspects of Trine 2 are the stunning visuals and alluring atmospheric presentation of the setting. Each and every environment you explore is diverse, captivating, and charming. The ambiance really captures the mystical aura of the game perfectly. Trine 2 somehow even manages to feel even more mystical than the first, and also has one of the most immersive 2D environments in the realm of video games.

The gameplay is light and quick to grasp. Anyone should be able to dive right in, regardless of ability level. But various difficulty levels and a “hardcore” mode ensure that skilled players can still find a challenge. And whether you are playing on “easy” or “hardcore,” the gameplay is entertaining. Trine 2 also offers a decent amount of increased depth to the character development aspects of the game compared to the first installment of the franchise. There are more abilities and items; and more varied strategies are needed to solve the puzzles.

As a direct sequel, the whimsical narrative is continued from the first game and the endearing trio of characters return. Even though it is a direct sequel, though, the story is quite separated from the original. So it won’t be the end of the world if you haven’t played the first game; but you probably should because it is also fantastic.

Also the option of playing in cooperative mode adds an additional layer of possibilities, as the unique gameplay of the Trine series is a joy to experience with friends.

So like I did with the first game, I would say that Trine 2 is worthy of your consideration regardless of your standard preferences. Check it out.

reviewText:
TL;DR  : Trine 2 is a platformer / puzzle game, and is one of the best coop games I've played. The game is gorgeous and runs very well, but the story is quite meh imo.

Story / Setting

Really wasn't the best part of the game, I'm not into these stereotypical RPG game stories. The characters and dialogues can be fun sometimes, but that's it. Maybe I wasn't paying attention, but I feel like the game doesn't even explain what the Trine is, and the backstory simply wasn't interesting. The content of the hidden chests disapointed me every time, but well, at least I got the achievements that went with it.

Gameplay

The game really shines when you're playing with someone, online or localy like I did. It can be fun alone but cooperating with someone makes it way better, wether its for the puzzles or for the combat. The only issue can be the point of view when playing multi, its not always easy to see some areas where things can be hidden, but it might be the same in single player which I haven't tried.

Overall the game is easy, a few puzzles took us a few minutes but that's it. If you really want to find everything in this game it'll be more about looking everywhere than solving hard puzzles. Some entrances can be hard to find. The fact that you can just rearange the skills of your characters made it a bit too easy as well. Same thing with the respawn system, you can die on and on and on and respawn a few meters behind, whereas the enemies keep all the damage you've done to them.

Some achievements are a bit harder and were the only real challenges in this game, but all of them were fun to get.


Performance

Wonderful graphics, even for 720p mid quality. it runned at 30 fps with these setttings which was enough for me in a game like this one (no need for high response time or super smooth gameplay like in a FPS)

Style / Graphics

It was probaly the best looking game I've been able to play on my laptop. Every map or areas is full of great lightning, creatures, buildings... etc.

TL;PL  : Trine 2 est un platformer, et est un des meilleurs jeu coop auquel j'ai pu jouer. Le jeu est magnifique et tourne bien, même si l'histoire n'etait pas très intéressante.

Histoire

Clairement pas le meilleur élement du jeu, ce genre d'histoire de RPG stéreotypées sont assez lourdes. Les dialogues et les personnages sont marrants parfois, mais c'est tout. Peut-être que je n'ais pas fait attention, mais je crois que le jeu n'explique même pas ce qu'est le Trine. Le contenu des coffres etait décevant à chaque fois, mais bon au moins ça permet d'obtenir des succès.

Gameplay

Il faut vraiment jouer au jeu en multijoueur pour l'apprecier complétement, que ce soit en ligne ou localement comme j'ai fait. Ca peut etre sympa tout seul mais le fait de coopérer avec quelqu'un rends le jeu milles fois mieux, que ce soit pour les puzzles ou les combats. Le seul problème en multi est le point de vue de la camera, c'est pas toujours facile de voir certaines zones à l'ecran, où certains objets peuvent être cachés, mais c'est peut-être la même chose en un joueur.

Globalement le jeu est vraiment facile, certains puzzles nous ont pris quelques minutes mais pas plus. Pour tout trouver dans ce jeu, c'est plus une question de regarder partout que de résoudre des puzzles compliqués. Certaines entrées peuvent être vraiment difficiles à trouver. Le fait que l'on peut simplement changer les compétences que l'on a assignés aux personnages rend également le jeu un peu trop facile. Pareil avec le système de respawn, on peut mourrir autant de fois qu'on veut et réapparaitre un peu derrière, alors que les ennemis gardent tous les dégats infligés.

Certains succès etaient compliqués et ont été le seul vrai challenge du jeu, mais tous les succès sont sympas à obtenir.

Performance

Les graphismes sont supers beaux, meme en 720p et qualité moyenne. Le jeu tourne à 30 fps avec ces options ce qui est assez pour ce genre de jeu à mon avis (pas besoin d'un temps de réponse très rapide ou de gameplay très fluide, comme dans un FPS)

Style / Graphismes

Probablement le plus beau jeu auquel j'ai pu jouer sur mon portable. Chaque map a de supers effets de lumières, et de très beaux batiments et créatures.

Gameplay 8/10:
Each of the three playable characters comes with a satisfying and well-balanced kit, though after a few upgrades, synergistic puzzle-skipping patterns emerge. So, in a sense, levelling up is being punished by making the puzzle elements of the game less challenging. The same can't be said for the combat elements since the game offers two difficulty sliders that can provide a fair challenge to any team, pulling thus the genre shift known as this-is-a-great-platformer-oh-no-it's-a-beat-em-up.

Plot 5/10:
A scarcely noteworthy plot that should have been better, considering the craftsmanship that went into this game.

Character 3/10:
The heroes all suffer from caricature syndrome. The Trine is underdeveloped. The woman is what, a queen or something? The goblin king is a baddie. The other final boss likes to kidnap old ladies and suffers from asthma? I don't know.

Diction 7/10:
Though at some points it can ring false, it maintains qualities suitable to the characters.

Melody 7/10:
The only grievance one would have with the soundtrack is repetition. You got yer battle music, yer boss music, yer exploration music, and that's 'bout it, I reckon.

Spectacle 10/10:
This game is the absolute definition of beauty. Forget the gradual polycount increase you see in tech demos that add gameplay as an afterthought. Forget the pseudo-artistic vomit that comprises of nothing but dark silhouettes or blocky sprites that preys on the clueless hipster. Here is a very finely crafted and detailed game world that comes alive, despite only utilizing two dimensions of space.

Final verdict:
It's the quintessential 3-way co-op side-scrolling puzzle platformer/beat-em-up on PC. Do not settle for imitation products; buy Trine 2 today!

Trine 2's fantasy vibe has a fun, unpretentious feel that evokes the loving tongue-in-cheek mannerisms that David Bowie exhibited in Labyrinth. Much like in the original Trine, you command a trio of adventurers who navigate a fantastical world in a classic rightward direction. Each of the three heroes have a distinct playstyle unto themselves: The Knight is adept at combat and can smash through heavy obstacles; the Thief can freeze enemies from a distance and use her grappling hook on certain surfaces; and the Wizard can conjure blocks and interact with the environment via telekinesis. You can switch between the three characters at any time -- and switch you will. This isn't a game where you pick a class and stick with it throughout the duration of the quest, as you'll quickly realize that each member of the fellowship is essential for completing every level. This is most apparent in the great multiplayer mode, which allows three people to roam the world together simultaneously. Gathering a pair of buddies and huddling around the television is a refreshing throwback to the days when single-system multiplayer was a norm in gaming.

The main flow of the game gets broken down into three distinct game types that cater to the abilities of each member of the trine. Combat areas play fairly simple, and can be easily completed by switching to the Knight and just slashing through your enemies. Contrary to this are the platforming segments, which grow more and more deadly as the game progresses. Even with the nimble grace of the Thief, you'll find yourself succumbing to the traps of the world on a fairly regular basis. Thankfully checkpoints are abundant, so you'll never be sent too far back. The final type of play involves using the Wizard to solve various puzzles. These challenges delve a bit deeper than remedial physics by forcing you to use levers, pulleys, and counterweights to unravel some of the more advanced scenarios. The game does a great job of divvying out those aha!" moments before any fun-destroying frustration sets in.

Trine 2's fantasy vibe has a fun, unpretentious feel that evokes the loving tongue-in-cheek mannerisms that David Bowie exhibited in Labyrinth. Much like in the original Trine, you command a trio of adventurers who navigate a fantastical world in a classic rightward direction. Each of the three heroes have a distinct playstyle unto themselves: The Knight is adept at combat and can smash through heavy obstacles; the Thief can freeze enemies from a distance and use her grappling hook on certain surfaces; and the Wizard can conjure blocks and interact with the environment via telekinesis. You can switch between the three characters at any time -- and switch you will. This isn't a game where you pick a class and stick with it throughout the duration of the quest, as you'll quickly realize that each member of the fellowship is essential for completing every level. This is most apparent in the great multiplayer mode, which allows three people to roam the world together simultaneously. Gathering a pair of buddies and huddling around the television is a refreshing throwback to the days when single-system multiplayer was a norm in gaming.

The main flow of the game gets broken down into three distinct game types that cater to the abilities of each member of the trine. Combat areas play fairly simple, and can be easily completed by switching to the Knight and just slashing through your enemies. Contrary to this are the platforming segments, which grow more and more deadly as the game progresses. Even with the nimble grace of the Thief, you'll find yourself succumbing to the traps of the world on a fairly regular basis. Thankfully checkpoints are abundant, so you'll never be sent too far back. The final type of play involves using the Wizard to solve various puzzles. These challenges delve a bit deeper than remedial physics by forcing you to use levers, pulleys, and counterweights to unravel some of the more advanced scenarios. The game does a great job of divvying out those aha!" moments before any fun-destroying frustration sets in.

reviewText:
This is coming from someone who never played (or heard of) the first Trine and played with a friend on the Medium difficulty. I’ve played it a bit in single player before doing that, and I wasn’t terribly impressed with it.

Trine 2 is basically a playable fairytale; it’s not a very interesting story, but it’s set in a very charming and magical world. The playable cast are the traditional Mage-Warrior-Thief combo, but they each are quite charming in their own way (like the world of Trine itself). Amadeus (the Mage) can create boxes and planks, Pontius (the Warrior) is a great fighter and can use his shield to both fly and protect himself and his allies, and Zoya (the Thief) is, quite refreshingly, an archer with lots of nifty tricks up her sleeves. All three are rather stereotypical: Amadeus is a smart coward scared of his wife, Pontius is a gluttonous stereotypical hero more concerned with food and saving princesses and Zoya is a shifty, greedy woman. Sadly, they don’t seem to really interact all that much during the game except during moments where the player has little (if any) control. It’s a shame because the personalities clash so much that it makes for some fairly amusing dialogue.

I can happily say that while this game is a sequel to Trine, it never feels like you missed anything. Sure, there are some little references to it (as far as I can tell, at least), but it’s a standalone story in its own right. Sure, it’s nothing special to begin with, but it’s refreshing to play a little fairytale instead of this big complex story with multiple plot twists. It took my friend and I about 8 hours to finish the main game (I’ll edit this when we do the DLC) and it never was too hard, though I would recommend playing on Classic and not Unlimited, as that really does force you to work together and not independently. However, I would also highly recommend playing the game with two players instead of three or one for reasons I’ll delve into later.

This is mainly a puzzle game where you have to find a way to go from point A to point B with all the tools given to you, such as boxes, pipes, fire, portals and more. However, there are a TON of hidden little nooks and crannies scattered throughout the game, and since it’s mainly EXP (because yes, there is a levelling system), it’s actually rewarding in a concrete way. There are also hidden paintings, which are basically concept art, and hidden poems, which are foreshadowing the story. Not necessary, but certainly fun to hunt down.

Notice how I said this is mainly a puzzle game. There are little combat breaks in the game that seem to separate puzzles, which is a welcome addition. However, they lead to a problem within the mechanics of the game and they’re why I can’t recommend playing this with three players (on Classic). To properly explain, however, I have to address the levelling system. It’s quite simple: pick up 50 hidden doohickeys and you level up, gaining a skill point for your account that can be used for either Amadeus, Pontius or Zoya. Amadeus will be able to create more objects, Pontius mainly gains combat abilities and Zoya gains different kinds of arrows that can assist in both utility and combat. As a result, Amadeus will not be very useful during combat, while Pontius and Zoya will be very useful (especially Pontius). The problem here is not quite Amadeus: it’s Pontius.

See, the bulk of the game is puzzle-based, so Pontius can’t really do much but stand around and wait for the others to clear the way to the next battle. Furthermore, his special ability (breaking rocks and wood) becomes obsolete as soon as Zoya gains explosive arrows, which are much more flexible since a lot of the hidden EXP bottles are hidden up high. Therefore, the player stuck with Pontius (in a 3P Classic situation) would be mostly useless and Amadeus finds himself helpless during battle (he can help, but not as much as the others). As a result, I found that playing with two players, one dedicated to Amadeus and one dedicated to Zoya, led with the most satisfying game experience as we could switch to Pontius whenever needed instead of having deadweight with us. We didn’t even need to get Pontius’ skills until Zoya (for me) and Amadeus (for my friend) had all their skills unlocked.

While the game is very, very forgiving (except, I’m guessing, on Hardcore), having lots of checkpoints that fully heal every character as often as you wish, there are still some annoyances (provided you don’t mind how forgiving the game is, which I didn’t). This mainly comes with the few ‘boss’ battles that appear throughout the game. They always take the same form: a big goblin with a massive club. Furthermore, this goblin kills anyone in a single hit and takes a fair bit to kill compared to other enemies, which is quite annoying. Also, I can’t imagine fighting the last boss in single player, though it’s a great fight where, once again, Pontius isn’t very useful.

Visually, the game is actually pretty stunning, being very colorful. Lots of shadows and lighting make the game ‘pop’ and seem alive. You can clearly see everything on the screen even when it’s dark, which I feel is crucial in a puzzle game as the main challenge shouldn’t be finding the pieces, but figuring out how they fit into one another. The music is also very pretty, being very soothing most of the time and kicking up the tempo and intensity when needed. However, none of the songs really stick in your head, instead blending into an immersive soundscape.

The whole game, being a playable fairytale, has a delightful cartoony feel to it, from the character designs to the story to the sounds and visual design. While the shallow combat seems a little tacked on and only created to give Pontius a purpose, the combat scenes are so short that it shouldn’t be counted as a huge negative.

I would highly recommend this game for 2P coop players and cautiously recommend it for 3P coop players and single players, as I feel the former would leave one player bored (assuming they play on Classic, as Unlimited is simply too easy as far as I’m concerned) and the latter feels like it’s missing something. The game isn’t too hard either, making it perfect for both casual and hardcore players, though it does seem more casual. Nevertheless, it’s a nice little game that’s definitely worth your time.

Do note, however, that the trailer (quite sadly) shows more of the DLC than the game itself. I’ll edit this when my friend and I get through the DLC, but know that it’s like a sequel (or a part 2) to the game; Trine 2 itself has 13 chapters and the DLC adds 7, to give you an idea. Who knows, maybe my complaints are fixed in the DLC?

This is a game for you if you like platforming and lite puzzle solving. The game also features very stunning visuals throughout the entire playthrough. Most of the level backgrounds are impressive and give the platforming layout a nice sense of depth.

Hard difficulty is recommended as the various traps can be run through in easy and medium difficulties without taking much damage. In hard difficulty you usually die instantly if you try to run through the traps like a headless chicken.

Online co-op is available for maximum of 3 players which I highly recommend as every character has their distinctive (and important) roles to play. The character roles also become more apparent when you play co-op as you can't swap between the characters (like in offline) as you please (if you disable the option), but need to work together to overcome the obstacles. Plus, it's always funny when someone screws up and as a result the whole group dies instantly.

The three playable characters are wizard, knight and thief.

Wizard can conjure various metallic platforms to jump on and is especially useful to reach some of the very hard to reach places. He also has a cute wizard's hat which usually flies off hilariously when he dies.

Knight has a shield + sword combo for defence, and to assist the wizard with platform creation he can magnetize the shield. Knight can use the shield to glide through the air like Mary Poppins.
Knight also has a big hammer which he can use to bash enemies and break wooden objects.

Thief is the nimble one as she can use grappling arrows to swing from wooden surface to another. She also has few stealth tricks to confuse the enemies, and can create low gravity bubble which comes in handy from time to time in co-op. In addition to normal arrows the thief can also shoot ice and fire/explosive arrows.

The levels are scattered with experience bubbles and vials which are used to unlock all the abilities of the characters. In addition the levels feature treasure chests in various secret places which unlock poems and concept art that can be viewed from the main menu gallery.

Checkpoints are frequent throughout the levels. Characters are healed (amount depends on difficulty) and resurrected at the checkpoints.

Enemies are mostly goblins with various equipment like shields, spears and armour. The enemies drop experience and sometimes health pickups that heal every member of the party. Levels also have themed wild life which can both aid and hinder your progress.

As a negative point the cutscenes cannot be skipped in multiplayer which isn't a problem in first playthrough, but can become tedious if you're planning to play it through more than once in co-op.

Aside from few lackluster boss level (which is good but not groundbreaking ) and some minor glitches here and there - Trine 2 is a gamer delight - oozing with beautiful graphics, bright colour, great gameplay with ever changing dynamics and tactics makes the game a must have item in your game library. Here's hoping that the next installment will be even more challenging and gorgeous than ever.

reviewText:
This is a long review so if you want just a brief summary of why I recommend Trine 2 then skip to Results and read from there.

Frozenbyte strikes again with a continuation of to the epic Trine series. Trine 2 takes all the great aspects of the original and makes it so much better. With improved graphics, smoother gameplay, better character customization, and more levels Trine 2 is a brilliant continuation.

Story:
The kingdom has recovered from the turmoil that struck in Trine. The heroes are being summoned again by the powerful Trine. Goblins have attacked the kingdom again, but who are they being led by. Crown Princess Rosabel asks them to help her rid her kingdom of the evil that if not dealt with will destroy everything.  As you progress you will learn about the Rosabel and her sister Isabel. How did the kingdom change since the last adventure and why did the Trine summon the same heroes?

Campaign:
The campaign consists of thirteen levels which start off with a brief tutorial as seen in the original and twelve additional levels. The levels are a lot longer than in the original offering more puzzles and secrets. Throughout the campaign you will fight three bosses each more challenging than the last. You will find secret poems, portraits, and more throughout the campaign which make you want to go back and search over again.

Gameplay:
Trine 2 gives you the same characters as the original: Amadeus (the wizard), Pontius (the knight), and Zoya (the thief). Unlike the original Trine there are no real items in this version just the basic experience orbs/jars, health potions, and chests with secrets inside. The skill trees are different than in the first one as well, they offer about the same amount of abilities. These abilities let you conjure more items, and use them in different ways. In Trine 2 you play as one character as a time, but you can switch though them instantly. If one of the characters die you respawn as one of the other two characters nearby. The brilliant combat system allows you to choose how you play the game. You can be hack ‘n slash melee hero (the Knight), a magical spell user (the Wizard), or an archer (the Thief).

Results:
Trine 2 is an epic platformer that pushes the ideas of original series by combining puzzle solving, hack ‘n slash, platformer, and RPG into a single game. The campaign offers secret items, poems and portraits, which reveal even more depth to the story. The brilliant story combined with beautiful level design and hundreds of secrets creates a fantastic game that does justice to the amazing series. Trine 2 is a game I would buy a full price and offers much more than other platformers, but if you are unsure and can get it on sale then I wouldn’t hesitate for a second.

Pros:
+Character customization
+Amazing story
+Beautiful scenery and level design
+Elegant music and ambience
+Fantastic combat systems
+Awesome boss fights that keep you pressed
+Brilliant voice acting and cut-scenes

Cons:
-Removed items that allowed you to further customize your characters

Trine 2 CS is an enchanting 2D side scroller game that steps into the realm of realism and jaw dropping graphics. Trine 2 bestow us with spectacular scenarios with ever changing level dynamics that shifts its paradigm with every level, the level of detail immerse you and binds you deeply into the game.

Aside from few lackluster boss level (which is good but not groundbreaking ) and some minor glitches here and there - Trine 2 is a gamer delight - oozing with beautiful graphics, bright colour, great gameplay with ever changing dynamics and tactics makes the game a must have item in your game library. Here's hoping that the next installment will be even more challenging and gorgeous than ever.

reviewText:
This is a game for you if you like platforming and lite puzzle solving. The game also features very stunning visuals throughout the entire playthrough. Most of the level backgrounds are impressive and give the platforming layout a nice sense of depth.

Hard difficulty is recommended as the various traps can be run through in easy and medium difficulties without taking much damage. In hard difficulty you usually die instantly if you try to run through the traps like a headless chicken.

Online co-op is available for maximum of 3 players which I highly recommend as every character has their distinctive (and important) roles to play. The character roles also become more apparent when you play co-op as you can't swap between the characters (like in offline) as you please (if you disable the option), but need to work together to overcome the obstacles. Plus, it's always funny when someone screws up and as a result the whole group dies instantly.

The three playable characters are wizard, knight and thief.

Wizard can conjure various metallic platforms to jump on and is especially useful to reach some of the very hard to reach places. He also has a cute wizard's hat which usually flies off hilariously when he dies.

Knight has a shield + sword combo for defence, and to assist the wizard with platform creation he can magnetize the shield. Knight can use the shield to glide through the air like Mary Poppins.
Knight also has a big hammer which he can use to bash enemies and break wooden objects.

Thief is the nimble one as she can use grappling arrows to swing from wooden surface to another. She also has few stealth tricks to confuse the enemies, and can create low gravity bubble which comes in handy from time to time in co-op. In addition to normal arrows the thief can also shoot ice and fire/explosive arrows.

The levels are scattered with experience bubbles and vials which are used to unlock all the abilities of the characters. In addition the levels feature treasure chests in various secret places which unlock poems and concept art that can be viewed from the main menu gallery.

Checkpoints are frequent throughout the levels. Characters are healed (amount depends on difficulty) and resurrected at the checkpoints.

Enemies are mostly goblins with various equipment like shields, spears and armour. The enemies drop experience and sometimes health pickups that heal every member of the party. Levels also have themed wild life which can both aid and hinder your progress.

As a negative point the cutscenes cannot be skipped in multiplayer which isn't a problem in first playthrough, but can become tedious if you're planning to play it through more than once in co-op.

reviewText:
This is a long review so if you want just a brief summary of why I recommend Trine 2 then skip to Results and read from there.

Frozenbyte strikes again with a continuation of to the epic Trine series. Trine 2 takes all the great aspects of the original and makes it so much better. With improved graphics, smoother gameplay, better character customization, and more levels Trine 2 is a brilliant continuation.

Story:
The kingdom has recovered from the turmoil that struck in Trine. The heroes are being summoned again by the powerful Trine. Goblins have attacked the kingdom again, but who are they being led by. Crown Princess Rosabel asks them to help her rid her kingdom of the evil that if not dealt with will destroy everything.  As you progress you will learn about the Rosabel and her sister Isabel. How did the kingdom change since the last adventure and why did the Trine summon the same heroes?

Campaign:
The campaign consists of thirteen levels which start off with a brief tutorial as seen in the original and twelve additional levels. The levels are a lot longer than in the original offering more puzzles and secrets. Throughout the campaign you will fight three bosses each more challenging than the last. You will find secret poems, portraits, and more throughout the campaign which make you want to go back and search over again.

Gameplay:
Trine 2 gives you the same characters as the original: Amadeus (the wizard), Pontius (the knight), and Zoya (the thief). Unlike the original Trine there are no real items in this version just the basic experience orbs/jars, health potions, and chests with secrets inside. The skill trees are different than in the first one as well, they offer about the same amount of abilities. These abilities let you conjure more items, and use them in different ways. In Trine 2 you play as one character as a time, but you can switch though them instantly. If one of the characters die you respawn as one of the other two characters nearby. The brilliant combat system allows you to choose how you play the game. You can be hack ‘n slash melee hero (the Knight), a magical spell user (the Wizard), or an archer (the Thief).

Results:
Trine 2 is an epic platformer that pushes the ideas of original series by combining puzzle solving, hack ‘n slash, platformer, and RPG into a single game. The campaign offers secret items, poems and portraits, which reveal even more depth to the story. The brilliant story combined with beautiful level design and hundreds of secrets creates a fantastic game that does justice to the amazing series. Trine 2 is a game I would buy a full price and offers much more than other platformers, but if you are unsure and can get it on sale then I wouldn’t hesitate for a second.

Pros:
+Character customization
+Amazing story
+Beautiful scenery and level design
+Elegant music and ambience
+Fantastic combat systems
+Awesome boss fights that keep you pressed
+Brilliant voice acting and cut-scenes

Cons:
-Removed items that allowed you to further customize your characters

Trine 2  is a puzzle platform game where you can constantly switch among three characters each with unique skills that complement each other -- and that's what sets this apart from other platform puzzle games.  In many cases there are more than one way to solve the puzzle so you can often stick with the character that matches your style.  In addition to puzzles there are semi-hidden chests and orbs that grant you points to upgrade your abilities.  I think finding the hidden stuff was one of the top high lights of the game.

The game also mixes in fight and boss sequences giving a nice balance between puzzle solving and action.  Thus I found the game more enjoyable than say a pure puzzle platform game like Limbo.  The game includes several achievements as well as a multiplayer mode giving you many hours of enjoyment.  Highly recommended.

reviewText:
Another spectacular,mesmerizing,gorgeous,endearing and utterly charming entry.
A definite Downloadable GOTY of 2011.

I loved the first Trine. The game came out of nowhere and blew me away. My friend and I finished the game on co-op although I had to plow through the last agonizing and infuriating level by myself, but that's beside the point.

If anyone ever played and loved Lost Vikings on Sega, this game is definitely for you. This Nvidia phys X physics engine is still limited to a two dimensional game but I can see it expanding further. Although this time around the engine can pump out even pretties graphics and textures which I didn't think was possible.


The soundtrack is amazing, it calms down your nerves and makes you forget about all the worries in the world. The author was the one who made the soundtrack for the Angry Birds by the way. The narration is realistic and believable. The game once again feels like watching and playing a fantasy tale. At times, I simply wished to simply run forward and sink in the world of Trine without any enemies or obstacles. I just wanted to enjoy the foreground, the background, the physics, the tessellation particles, etc.


As with the first game, you collect vials and then use them for upgrades. 90% of the vials are more or less easy to obtain, much like in the first game; and there are several ways of obtaining almost every vial. You no longer retain your upgrades and abilities from the first game, so you have to reacquire the old ones as well as obtain only a couple of new ones.

Apparently the story takes place a few years after the first game. The awkward alleged womanizer wizard Amadeus is older now and is now a family man. Pontius is still the dumb and fearless fat knight and Zoya is still the same slender thief.

The trio is quickly reunited for a quest to save the kingdom, again.

The thief is still my personal favorite character to play. The acrobatics are still rewarding to conduct and you want to pat yourself on the back every time you manage to shoot the grappling hook as you fall to your death and suspend yourself in mid air. The thief will be the one to get most of the vials, artifacts and other miscellaneous collectibles (like drawings and poems) from hard-to-reach areas anyway. However, later on the wizard becomes extremely effective since you are then able to conjure several items and be able to float yourself and the entire party across impassable lands.The physics and the general precision is once again impeccable. The story now introduces orcs as opposed to the same old boring skeletons and other creatures. There are a handful of bosses still and they are fun to battle. The melee system is still as refined as in part 1. You can block, swing, shoot arrows and use the environment to your advantage (for instance dropping a rock onto an enemy while playing as a Wizard)

The game CAN get frustrating sometimes, especially when you attempt again and again to jump on that ledge or attempt to swing over and get that orb or vial. It's not the fault of the controls per se, it's the physics and the gravity that often prevent you from conducting flawless maneuvers.

The game apparently also has more replay value than the first one. There are more unlockables and extras this time. Once you finish the game, you can start a new game + and experience some new things, allegedly. PLUS, this time we get online co-op. Yes, thank you very much. Whereas the first game only featured a 2 player offline co-op, someone always had to be the brains and play as the two characters most of the time. Not this time. Now you can play as one of the three characters. You can use either text or voice chat to coordinate movement. I strongly recommend playing this game in co-op mode. It might get repetitive at times, but no puzzle is every the same so there is still enough variety, plus I don't think I saw a single piece of environment being recycled.

In general the game is quite easy. It does not call for a repeated frustration. There are plenty of checkpoints that will resurrect your dead companions and there are almost always more than one way of overcoming an obstacle.

The bottom line is that this game makes you regret that the world of Trine is only confined to a video game.

reviewText:
-Quick Review-
Trine 2, is a 2D platformer that combines three different heroes into one (if you’re playing single player) or select one hero and work with two or three friends to try to complete the various puzzles in the game.
-Detailed breakdown review-
Story:  You are summoned by the Trine (A mysterious Dwarven object), which links a Wizard “Amadeus” , a Knight “Pontius” and a thief/entrepreneur “Zoya” together to save the kingdom. The story itself is put together like a bed time story, very straight forward and amusing to listen to.

Game Play: (note, at this time 06/20/14 – I have not played the original Trine) As has been hinted above in the story section, you can switch between three very different heroes. You can actually complete the levels without switching at all, but generally switching makes solving puzzles much easier.
There is a little bit of combat where you need to smash in some Goblin heads, but the most challenging aspect of the game is the environments which are definitely out to kill me. Plenty of death holes in the ground.
There is also a quaint leveling system in the game, when you collect “experience orbs” you level up and are given a skill point to assign to a character and ability. By upgrading skills you make puzzle solving much easier and often times dynamic. I’ve solved puzzles with Amadeus’s boxes that I could have done faster and easier the “correct way”. But that aspect gives the game a sense of freedom.

Multi-player:  I had the privilege to play this game with a friend, and let me say this game is amazingly more fun to play with one or two friends. The difference is that if you are playing with others, you are limited to which character you play as. If you’re playing with just one friend, which leaves one free character either of you can switch or rotate with. (For us, it was Pontius… Sorry buddy, you’re good at fighting, not at plat forming).

Achievements: Here’s the basic break down for the achievements: Collect all the things, Find all the things, Do a few special things with each character, then Beat the game on Hard core mode on Hard difficulty, and you’ll have all the achievements.
The game has 97 achievements, I was surprised that a game like Trine 2 had so many achievements, but it provided a great deal of entertainment and a fair bit of replay-ability to get the rest of the achievements.

Price: The price for Trine 2 is $19.99. I played 30 hours (and that will increase as I work on getting the hard core achievements) that is a pretty fair price for how much time I’ve put into it. Good news though! We are in the Steam Summer sale (06/20/14)! The game is on sale right now for 85% off, in other words the game is $2.99 That is a great deal, if you’ve been wanting to play a platformer puzzle fantasy game, now is your time. You have until June 30th to get it at this current price.
If you’re still not sure if you’d like to play it or not, you can also download a demo to test out first; you can’t be persuaded anymore than that.

Conclusion: I really enjoyed the game. If you’re just looking to relax and play a fantasy adventure game, I highly recommend this game. It was fun to play, not overly difficult however the Hardcore kicked my butt; it’s not something you’ll just waltz through. But the easiest difficulties make the game seem very friendly.

Coming off it's success of Trine, Trine has lost none of it's glamour, and in the process has added only everything wonderful. I really enjoyed the first trine. It's story, music, gameplay, all of it was generally delightful, allbeit short. Trine 2 follows wonderfully in it's footsteps.

Here we find our three heroes not really looking for adventure per say, but the Trine once again find it for them. This time they are taken off to save a world of enchantment and a battle between sisters. In the process they find themselves fighting goblins. There is no reason to argue with story line here, as the story is short, succinct, not complicated, and enjoyable for the game.

In terms of gameplay, Trine 2 builds on it's predecessor, working out many of the physics kinks that were so lauded. The characters do basically the same thing, with the addition of a few extras - the knights glide, and magnet shield, the thiefs special gravity arrow, and ability to hide herself, and the wizards magnetic objects, and ability to trap enemies inside boxes, as well as ability to pick up enemies. All in all, the gameplay of this game is smooth and for the most part without problems. 9.5/10

In terms of graphics, Trine 2 looks superb. The artists who worked the concepts of this game have done a phenomenal job yet again. The colours, the look, and the increased depth make this side-scroller look even better. The graphics themselves could be a little nicer, sharper, and slightly more realistic in some areas - the characters for instance - but all in all this game is more than pleasing on the eyes. 9/10

Music in this game is one thing that I really enjoy. The embience coupled with the wonderful sound track is above par. Music is a lost art when it comes to video games sometimes, but Trine 2, like it's predecessor, does an excellent job of creating wonderful atmosphere and putting the right music at the right time. And just add in here, the narration of Trine 2 is just as fun as the first. 9.5/10 (BTW, I'm a music teacher)

Co-op is such a hard thing to get right. It's hard to know when it's too much, or when it's not enough. It's a good thing that co-op over the internet was added to this game. It makes it so much more fun to play that way. The only drawaback to this games co-op is the same as last times, the controller configuration. More often then I would like to admit, the control configurations seem to be out of wack. Responding to the wrong thing, or not working at all. Multiple keyboards is still an impossible task sometimes. The co-op itself is fun to play with friends, but if the work on controller configuration were fixed the co-op would be even more fun. 8.5/10

Overall, this game is wonderful. It can be short, or long, depending on what you plan to do with it. It can be easy, or you can challenge yourself, as I have, to find new ways to beat certain areas. If you find it too easy, put it in hardcore mode, on hard, then give it a whirl. Enjoy the colours, the embience, and try and find a friend to play this game with you. You won't win any major tournaments while shooting dozens of people, but you will find yourself enjoying the fact that you've made it through a game using your brain.

It sounds confusing but it's easy once you experience it.

Lets say you have an enemy that is best suited to be taken down with brute force. Push left bumper, swittch to my brawler and take them down. 3 seconds later, I have a puzzle that requires some blocks to be moved around. Push left bumber, switch to my wizard. Move those blocks with my magic. 3 seconds later I have an obsticle that requires a finess jump. Push left bumper, switch to my archer/acrobat. Jump over that obsicle.

It's really just fun. Pure and simple. If you like platformers. If you like modern, rich graphic, puzzle solving platformers, then I bet you will enjoy this game.

I'll update this review after I finish the game... but so far I'm thoroughly impressed.

There's rarely a game that I play where I have to pause a moment every now and then to appreciate the beauty of every details in the scene. There's also rarely a game where I enjoy missing most platforms and going back to try again and again.

One of my favorite game series ever.  If you're one for sidescrolling action and puzzle solving, this is for you!  And did  I mention?  Online co-op!

Puzzle games have, like many genres, evolved significantly since their arrival onto home consoles. We can look back on titles such as Adventures of Lolo[en.wikipedia.org] for the NES, and Doki Doki Penguin Land[en.wikipedia.org] for the Sega Master system, it’s easy to see how far we’ve come. Trine 2 is an example of gaming evolution done right; it takes its foundation from the platforming genre and implements many other elements to provide us with art, action, and strategy… with a bit of frustration thrown in for good measure.

When starting up Trine 2 for the first time, the first thing that will catch anyone’s attention is the incredibly bright atmosphere. Frozenbyte did a wonderful job of providing the player with visual stimulation in the form of exceptional graphics, bright colors and detailed environments. This is something that is usually not the center of focus for puzzle games, but they managed to make it the most eye-popping aspect for me. I was simply blown away at how impressive the artwork was, and how it created a realistic looking environment; it's an enticing environment that satisfies many emotions. A prime example of this being the level. “Searock Castle,” a level that presents many hazards like any other, but is so pleasurable to the eyes that I often found myself saying, “huh... this would be a nice vacation spot!” Of course, I would ask for the travel package that excluded the protoceratop-sized crabs, circulating flamethrowers and hostile ogre-like enemies.

Onto the secrets and puzzles. Each level has carefully hidden one to two treasure chests that contain either a painting or a poem. Sometimes the chests are in plain sight, and it's simply a matter of creating a strategy to access it. Other times it's in an obscure location that one would never consider venturing. Because of the uncertainty, many times I found myself hacking away at walls with my hammer to see if it was a destructible passageway. Although this may sound tedious, I liked this because it really made me want to explore the level, instead of progressing along like an assembly belt. The puzzles and obstacles themselves are also well done, but an apparently easy puzzle can quickly turn disaster with a simple misclick or a miscalculation of game physics. It puts the players problem solving skills, and patience, to the ultimate test. The keyword here is patience, and I cannot emphasize this enough, because players without patience will find themselves quite frustrated. A perfect example of this is when a player accidentally destroys an existing platform that he/she had previously created, or accidentally moving a box/plank to a location that requires you start over. You know the solution to the puzzle, you know that you can complete it, but you're required to start the entire process over again due to an accidental slip up or a misclick. This is not unique to Trine 2 in any way, as many puzzle games punish the players for a mix-up in controls or accuracy. But for some reason, it felt notably more frustrating in this game.

Which leads me to my next topic: The controls. I have mixed feelings on the controls. Initially, I was using a Logitech F310 gamepad, which has been my go-to gamepad for years now. The combat and movement felt flawless with the d-pad, and I never once found myself questioning my input commands.However, the analogue stick controls were an absolute nightmare, and I often found myself incredibly frustrated with inconsistent sensitivity, movements that felt random in nature, and collision physics that felt over-dramatic. To prevent further frustration, I switched to a mouse and keyboard halfway through the game. Right away, all of my frustrations subsided, and I felt like I was once again in control of my movements. Perhaps it's the accuracy of the mouse, but the analogue controls felt incredibly inaccurate when trying to be precise. I'm not pinning this entirely on the controls of Trine 2, as it's highly possible that my gamepad is simply not the ideal gamepad for this type of game. But for me, I found that the keyboard and mouse provided far, far more accurate and smooth controls.

The only moment of overwhelming frustration came during the end of the game, but it wasn't in the form of a puzzle or an obstacle. Well, perhaps it could be considered an obstacle, as I encountered a glitch that stopped me in my tracks. On the level “Icewarden Keep”, the player reaches a part where is a barrage of enemies that flood the area, along with a particularly strong enemy that emerges from a gate to your right... a gate that needs to open in order for the player to progress. Unfortunately, this gate never opened, and this enemy stood behind the gate swatting at thin air. This happened not once, but twice, both times requiring that I restart the entire level. This was especially frustrating since this level, in my opinion, was one of the most grueling ones in regards to difficulty. I did some research, and apparently I'm not the only one who has experienced this glitch. I was relieved when the gate finally opened, but was a bit upset that I had to truck through that brutally difficult level more than once.

The story is nothing overly special, but it has a nice touch to it. For a platforming puzzle game, one can't expect a legendary tale of sadness, revenge, love and deceit in the realm of Final Fantasy IX. Instead, it's a fairly streamlined story that addresses the subject matter in a linear and chapter-like fashion. Pleasant, but nothing overly memorable.

Overall, I highly recommend this game to those who are interested in a fluid, obstacle-based platforming puzzler. It's short, but sweet, and a fantastic entry to the genre. I would hesitate to recommend this game to those who may a prefer a bit more action in their games, and those who aren't particularly thrilled by the notion of extended puzzle solving. As I mentioned before, it's a game of patience, and this can be grueling for some. But for some like myself, it's all worth it just to have that sign of relief once you cross the finish line.

A trine is a group of three. It was also a clever 2009 puzzle platformer starring a trio of adventurers, each with specific talents. Lucky us, now we have a sequel, Trine 2, that offers more fun physics-based challenges, more beautiful vistas, and adds online multiplayer to the mix.

The first thing I noticed about Trine 2 is its stunning visuals. Each scene, from forests to caves to lazy beaches, shines with rich detail and startling lighting effects. There is always something amazing to distract you. Trine 2 easily makes for one of the prettiest games of the year.

If you played the first Trine, you'll find a very familiar game here. Players run from left to right through fantasy spectacles, surmounting obstacles and slaying a few goblins along the way. You have three heroes at your disposal: a wizard that can conjure blocks and platforms, a thief with a bow and grappling hook, and a knight with sword, hammer, and shield. The brilliance of Trine 2 is that it mostly leaves the choice of which hero to use up to you. I love it when a game lets me off my leash and tells me have fun
date:
-- and that's the kind of game Trine 2 is.

It does fail to teach the player some important mechanics, though, resulting in slight exasperation when you don't realize a solution is even possible. The wizards platforms, for instance, can be stuck to swinging spiked maces, resulting in a pendulum conveyance. That's really cool, but it would have been nice to get a heads-up before I found myself stuck at the bottom of an ice slope for a little too long.

When playing by yourself you switch between the three heroes at will. In a matter of moments you might slash through some goblins as the knight, switch to the thief to grapple to a high platform, then switch to the wizard to move a heavy block in front of a flame thrower. Trine 2 is also very friendly about multiplayer gaming, allowing up to three players to join the adventure either locally or online. I find the game becomes easier this way because you've got more than just one brain working on problems and you can multitask, but it's still satisfying.

The few boss fights prove slightly disappointing. While visually impressive, they don't require the same thought as the rest of Trine 2. Merely crossing a chasm can be a real conundrum, but felling a giant beast is as simple as giving it a few whacks to its weak spots. I do love the way the bosses are foreshadowed early on in levels, though.

Trine 2: Complete Story is an hybrid between a platform and puzzle game developed by developer Froze Byte and follows the adventure of three heroes, Amadeus the Magnificent, Zoya and Pontius the Brave, as they are guided by a mysterious magical entity, the titular Trine, to face a dark plot involving their kingdom. The Complet Story edition adds to the original some tweaks and include the only major DLC for the game, Goblin Menace, for free.
The main beef of Trine 2 is about using the unique perks and abilities of each character or combine them as needed in order to advance in the levels you are thrown in: while there are some enemy encounters through the game, they are a rarity and are easily overcame with the trio's basic abilities (even the few bosses featured are pretty straightforward, save for the final bosses, who are more puzzle game fare in nature). Amadeus the Magnificent doesn't have any combat abilities to speak of and is rather fragile, but can conjure crates or move elements of the scenery to help his comrades. Zoya, instead, is a classic rogue character: she can move faster and jump higher than the other two characters, use a grappling tool to swing around on wooden surfaces and damage enemies from afar using her bow and different kind of arrows. Finally, Portius the Brave is a very sturdy, shielded warrior who fills the role of the group's tank against enemies and heavy damage dealer: after unlocking some of his additional abilities, however, Portius also becomes useful during the platforming sections as a support character.
The levels of Trine 2 feature several experience orbs you can collect to level up your characters: each level gained unlocks an ability point you can spend in the talent tree of each hero. Some of these unlocked abilities only enhance the skills the characters already posses, while others introduce totally new gimmicks capable of making the later section of the game much easier to handle.
It can be argued that one of the main attraction in Trine 2 are its impressive visual, especially for being a side scroller game: all the characters and environments are rendered in great 3D detail and the scenaries are multiple layers to them. The art style also feels rather unique.
One of the main novelty of Trine 2 in comparison to the original game are its only features: a party of three players can experience the whole adventure while playing together online, each controlling his/her own character. On top of being a rather entertaining experience, the multiplayer element also makes the game easier to handle and mixing the heroes' powers much more straightforward.
Trine 2's replayability is a bit scarce: once you've been playing through the whole game and found a solution to all the puzzles and obstacles, the only real reason to come back for a second run is to play with your friends or change your default character. There are also collectables to be found inside the levels (pieces of poetry and paintings/concept art), but finding them isn't exactly a serious challenge.
The Goblin Menace DLC is the only additional content released for Trine 2 and follows the story of Amadeus, Zoya and Portius after their great adventure as they try to save Amadeus' wife from an aggressive army of goblins. The DLC doesn't offer any new gameplay elements whatsoever, both in general mechanics and characters' abilities: on the other side, however, it lasts for some interesting hours, has its own story and, if possible, the level design is even more complex and gorgeous than the one from the main game.
Trine 2: Complete Story is an entertaining game with its own peculiar identity and apparel that I found very enjoyable, moreso if taken on with a pair of friends along the way

This game builds on the previous game and has everything the previous game had. Gorgeous art, atmospheric soundtrack, excellent gameplay. The storyline is as almost nonexistent as in the first one, but essentially, Trine 2 sees you back in the shoes of the wizard, knight and thief as you try and find your way through the puzzle/platformer levels.

The abilities of the characters have been slightly re-jigged, in order to keep the gameplay fresh, but also to avoid the RPG trope where a character loses all the abilites he got in the first game at the beginnign of the sequel! The gameplay still works best with more than one player helping each other out - in fact, perhaps more so than the first due to the new abilities.

It has, particularly with the Gblin Menace expansion, a great amount of gameplay for the price. The Goblin Menace adds (amongst other things) another crazy boss level, but it's much more down to skill than insanity and pure blind luck like the first one! It still stands in my mind as one of the best examples of a final boss level - it involves using all the abilities and skills you've learnt and working with your co-players in a classic multi-stage boss level.

All in all, following on from the last one, 9/10 - it's brilliant fun multiplayer with an Xbox controller, but loses the one point for the lacklustre storyline and confusing keyboard controls.

Coming off it's success of Trine, Trine has lost none of it's glamour, and in the process has added only everything wonderful. I really enjoyed the first trine. It's story, music, gameplay, all of it was generally delightful, allbeit short. Trine 2 follows wonderfully in it's footsteps.

Here we find our three heroes not really looking for adventure per say, but the Trine once again find it for them. This time they are taken off to save a world of enchantment and a battle between sisters. In the process they find themselves fighting goblins. There is no reason to argue with story line here, as the story is short, succinct, not complicated, and enjoyable for the game.

In terms of gameplay, Trine 2 builds on it's predecessor, working out many of the physics kinks that were so lauded. The characters do basically the same thing, with the addition of a few extras - the knights glide, and magnet shield, the thiefs special gravity arrow, and ability to hide herself, and the wizards magnetic objects, and ability to trap enemies inside boxes, as well as ability to pick up enemies. All in all, the gameplay of this game is smooth and for the most part without problems. 9.5/10

In terms of graphics, Trine 2 looks superb. The artists who worked the concepts of this game have done a phenomenal job yet again. The colours, the look, and the increased depth make this side-scroller look even better. The graphics themselves could be a little nicer, sharper, and slightly more realistic in some areas - the characters for instance - but all in all this game is more than pleasing on the eyes. 9/10

Music in this game is one thing that I really enjoy. The embience coupled with the wonderful sound track is above par. Music is a lost art when it comes to video games sometimes, but Trine 2, like it's predecessor, does an excellent job of creating wonderful atmosphere and putting the right music at the right time. And just add in here, the narration of Trine 2 is just as fun as the first. 9.5/10 (BTW, I'm a music teacher)

More often then I would like to admit, the control configurations seem to be out of wack. Responding to the wrong thing, or not working at all. Multiple keyboards is still an impossible task sometimes. The co-op itself is fun to play with friends, but if the work on controller configuration were fixed the co-op would be even more fun. 8.5/10

Overall, this game is wonderful. It can be short, or long, depending on what you plan to do with it. It can be easy, or you can challenge yourself, as I have, to find new ways to beat certain areas. If you find it too easy, put it in hardcore mode, on hard, then give it a whirl. Enjoy the colours, the embience, and try and find a friend to play this game with you. You won't win any major tournaments while shooting dozens of people, but you will find yourself enjoying the fact that you've made it through a game using your brain.

A Magical ExperienceVery polished and creative, Trine 2 is a puzzle platformer like no other. Unlike other platformers, there isn't just one way to solve a puzzle in this game. At times you'll feel like you're cheating because you've found some way to bypass a puzzle--but that's the point! GameplayIn the game, you play as Amadeus, a wizard who can conjure boxes and bridges to allow you to climb to victory, Zoya, a thief whose grappling hook swings her from platform to platform, or Pontius, whose shield will defend you from even the most dangerous projectilles. You can always switch characters mid-level and combine their skills to beat the challenges you face. Or you can challenge yourself to beat a level using only the skills of one character!

And don't worry: there are secrets, collectibles, and achievements abound! Literally hours of gameplay outside of the main story are devoted to exploring this strange world.

VisualsThe graphics are crisp and evoke the feeling of a fantastical world very well. The game itself is 2D, but everything is rendered in 3D. The levels simply feel alive. Trine 2 is probably the most beautiful platformer I've ever played.

VerdictC'mon, get this game.

For fans of stereoscopic 3D gaming, this game is a must-buy.  There are many games which look fantastic in Nvidia 3d Vision, but the Trine games (especially 2 and 3) are so good as to be useful for modeling the technology, in my opinion.  Furthermore, unlike many games that work well in 3D Vision and nothing else, the Trine games have additional 3D modes to make the game compatible with pretty much any stereoscopic setup you have.  If you have a modern 3D TV and choose to play this game in 2D, you are doing yourself a serious disservice.  Get an extra-long hdmi cable, if you have to, and attach your computer to your TV!  (Or invest in a 3D Vision setup, if you are a fan of stereoscopic 3D movies and games.)

The game is oodles of fun with a friend, in both local and internet co-op, with the difference being that the two characters must share a screen for local co-op; netplay has no such limitation, and you can get separated if you are not careful.  That said, I recommend the latter for those who have both options available to then.

Sadly, the game has its share of internet MP bugginess, worse than the first game did (but not as bad as the third).  It was so bad that my friend and I (with him in America and me in Japan, both of us with excellent internet connections) were not able to complete the DLC's final boss, which is arguably broken for multiplayer (possibly local MP as well, given the way the boss spazzes out and gets confused when more than one target is available).  So while I must shake my finger at Frozenbyte for not play-testing and bug-proofing the multiplayer more, I cannot in good conscious give this anything other than a thumbs-up, for its combination of appealing platforming, charming characters and voice acting, and jaw-droppingly gorgeous visuals, which really must be viewed in stereoscopic 3D to be fully appreciated.

Artistic Value: 9.5
Fun Factor: 8 (probably lower while playing solo and/or in 2D)
My Score: 8.5
This game is a 10! Awesome with co-op, and a must have for anyone out there that likes puzzle games. It also happens to have some seriously kick-♥♥♥ graphics too, so check it out!

I bought this because it was on sale (2.99) at the time, and was looking for another puzzle co-op game to feed in to my Portal 2 co-op mode obsession. This was totally different, but fun, some replayability due to different ways of solving puzzles, flexible enough to work as both single and multiplayer, and definitely worth the 3 bucks when on sale, I'd even say probably worth the full prize. This is the first I've played of the series and may pick up the 1st and 3rd soon.
